had to verbalize what I believe

15.text:
accounts for the failure of most

18.text:
is the fact that I can
not bear love's aging.

22.text:
I cannot stand the dissolution
of the honeymoon phase, right.

29.text:
As soon as the vacation,
the electrifying vitality,

34.text:
the rapture of
meeting someone new

37.text:
fades it's a kind
of death practice.

43.text:
When enthralment
dissipates you kind of

47.text:
have a moment of profound
tragic realization

52.text:
that everything passes, that our
greatest ecstasies are imbued,

58.text:
are cast upon by a shadow of
dread, of knowing that this

63.text: will pass, that this will end.

73.text:
So what do we do when we look
into the iris of a lover's eye,

78.text:
When being seen
by the person you

80.text:
love so much gives
you goose bumps,

82.text:
makes you cry, touches your
core, touches your soul,

89.text:
Makes you think of that
Roland Barthes books,

"Lover's Discourse," about
how the cradling that

94.text:
takes place between two
people when they finally

96.text:
feel safe, like Adam and

100.text:
before the tree of knowledge,
before knowledge of death,

111.text:
See, I want to live in
that garden of Eden.

I listen to beautiful
songs about it.

123.text:
I ate from the
tree of knowledge.

125.text:
I learned about death, and
mortality, and endings,

And I think that
that has haunted

this terror
